q: What is erectile dysfunction?
a: Erectile dysfunction is when you are either unable to get an erection or unable to keep an erection for long enough to have sex. It can also be accompanied by a low sex drive.

q: What are the causes of erectile dysfunction?
a: The causes of erectile dysfunction can vary and may include stress, tiredness, excessive alcohol consumption, side effects of medication, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, diabetes, depression, anxiety, or hormonal problems.

q: What are some things you can do to help with erectile dysfunction?
a: There are several lifestyle changes that can help with erectile dysfunction, such as losing weight, quitting smoking, eating a healthy diet, exercising regularly, reducing stress and anxiety, and avoiding excessive alcohol consumption or cycling for long periods of time.

q: When should you see a GP or go to a sexual health clinic for erectile dysfunction?
a: If you experience persistent erection problems, it is recommended to see a GP or visit a sexual health clinic as it could be a sign of an underlying health condition that can be treated.

q: How can sexual health clinics help with erection problems?
a: Sexual health clinics can provide the same treatments as GP surgeries and often offer a walk-in service without the need for an appointment. They can provide quicker test results compared to GP practices.

q: What happens at an appointment for erectile dysfunction?
a: During an appointment, the doctor or nurse may ask about your lifestyle, relationships, and any problems you might be having. They may also perform basic health checks and examine your genitals to rule out any physical causes.

q: What are the treatment options for erectile dysfunction?
a: The main treatments for erectile dysfunction are medicines that increase blood flow to the penis (PDE-5 inhibitors) such as sildenafil, tadalafil, vardenafil, and avanafil. Vacuum pumps can also be used, and there are treatments available for underlying causes like high blood pressure, high cholesterol, and hormonal problems. Counselling and therapy can help if erection problems are related to emotional or mental health.

q: Can you buy medications for erectile dysfunction online?
a: You can buy sildenafil (Viagra) online, but it's important to be cautious as many websites sell fake medicines. It's best to see a doctor before buying online to ensure safety and suitability. Make sure the online pharmacy is registered with the General Pharmaceutical Council (GPhC), the online doctor service is registered with the Care Quality Commission (CQC), and the doctors are registered with the General Medical Council (GMC).

q: What if medications are not suitable or do not work for erectile dysfunction?
a: If medications are not suitable or ineffective, vacuum pumps can be used to encourage blood flow to the penis. Treating the underlying cause of erectile dysfunction, such as switching to a different medication, addressing high blood pressure or high cholesterol, or seeking counselling or therapy for emotional or mental health problems, are alternative options to consider.

q: Are there private options for counselling or therapy for erectile dysfunction?
a: Yes, you can opt to see a counsellor or therapist privately. Counsellors and psychotherapists should be members of the British Association of Counselling and Psychotherapy, and sex therapists should be members of the College of Sexual and Relationship Therapists (COSRT) or the Institute of Psychosexual Medicine. Relate also offers sex therapy for a fee.

q: What is erectile dysfunction?
a: Erectile dysfunction is when you are either unable to get an erection or unable to keep an erection for long enough to have sex. It can be caused by various factors such as stress, tiredness, alcohol consumption, or underlying health conditions.

q: What are the causes of erectile dysfunction?
a: The causes of erectile dysfunction can vary and may include stress, tiredness, excessive alcohol consumption, certain medications, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, diabetes, depression or anxiety, and hormone problems.

q: What can I do to help with erectile dysfunction?
a: There are several lifestyle changes that may help with erectile dysfunction, such as losing weight if overweight, quitting smoking, maintaining a healthy diet, exercising regularly, and managing stress and anxiety. It's also advisable to limit alcohol intake and avoid prolonged cycling.

q: When should I see a GP or go to a sexual health clinic for erectile dysfunction?
a: If you experience persistent erection problems, it is advisable to see a GP or visit a sexual health clinic. It could be a sign of an underlying health condition that can be treated.

q: How can sexual health clinics help with erection problems?
a: Sexual health clinics can provide treatment for erection problems similar to what you would receive at a GP surgery. They often offer a walk-in service with quicker test results. You can find a sexual health clinic near you for assistance.

q: What happens during an appointment for erectile dysfunction?
a: During an appointment for erectile dysfunction, the doctor or nurse may ask about your lifestyle and relationships, perform basic health checks like taking your blood pressure, and examine your genitals to rule out any physical causes. In some cases, an examination of the prostate may also be conducted.

q: What are the treatments for erectile dysfunction?
a: The main treatments for erectile dysfunction are medications called PDE-5 inhibitors which increase blood flow to the penis. Examples include sildenafil (Viagra), tadalafil (Cialis), vardenafil (Levitra), and avanafil (Spedra). Vacuum pumps can also be used. Treating the underlying cause and therapy or counseling can be beneficial as well.

q: Can I buy medications for erectile dysfunction online?
a: You can buy sildenafil (Viagra) online, but it's important to be cautious as many websites sell fake medicines. Online medicines may not be regulated and can have varying ingredients and side effects. It's recommended to see a doctor before purchasing medications online.

q: Are vacuum pumps a suitable option for erectile dysfunction?
a: Vacuum pumps can be used to encourage blood flow to the penis and create an erection. They work for most men and can be an alternative if medications are not suitable or effective. However, they may not always be available through the NHS.

q: Are there private counselors or sex therapists for erectile dysfunction?
a: Yes, you can seek private counseling or therapy for erectile dysfunction. Make sure to choose a counselor or therapist who is a member of reputable organizations such as the British Association of Counselling and Psychotherapy or the College of Sexual and Relationship Therapists. Relate also offers sex therapy for a fee.
